documentation.title: Class action arbitration agreement
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Is it possible to have a class action if customers have agreed to a arbitration clause forbidding class action? Is their a way around the arbitration agreement? Does the arbitration agreement cover illegal or deceptive business practices intentionally set up to defraud unknowing customers? Lastly if someone has discovered a despicable business practice intentionally meant to mislead its customers resulting in millions of unearned income, is their a way for that person to get a portion of the settlement that doesn’t include being a plantiff in the class action. Similar to a finders fee for a lawyer bringing a case to a larger more capable firm but for a nonlawyer, so a legally viable alternative or options within the the extent of law.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The answer is unclear, but only minimally. There is a [trio of cases](http://www.scotusblog.com/case-files/cases/epic-systems-corp-v-lewis/) now being considered by SCOTUS, pertaining to the [Federal Arbitration Act](http://www.legisworks.org/congress/68/publaw-401.pdf) and its interaction with the National Labor Relations Act. Since the federal government doesn't get to totally write the law for everything, the FAA applies only to transactions covered by the Commerce Clause. As a result of [Allied\-Bruce Terminix Cos. v. Dobson](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/513/265/), that would include a state\-internal suit against a local exterminator.

In general, the FAA states that an award can be vacated in US courts if the arbitration itself is corrupt (e.d. fraudulent), but not if the subject matter if the dispute is about fraud. Federal law preempts state law ([Southland Corp. v. Keating](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/465/1/case.html), 465 U.S. 1\), so mandatory arbitration clauses are enforceable (unless the contract itself is invalid, e.g. duress, unconscionability). A state may not, however, declare that mandatory arbitration clauses render a contract unconscionable ([AT\&T Mobility v. Concepcion](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/563/333/opinion.html), 563 U.S. 333\), as California had done in [Discover Bank. Laster v. AT\&T Mobility LLC, 584 F. 3d 849](https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/1436159/laster-v-at-t-mobility-llc/?).

92.answer:
Based on the provided documentation, here's a challenging multiple-choice question that meets the specified criteria:

Question: A large tech company has included a mandatory arbitration clause in its user agreement that prohibits class actions. Several users discover that the company has been secretly collecting and selling personal data, violating privacy laws. A group of affected users wants to challenge this practice. Which of the following approaches is most likely to succeed in circumventing the arbitration clause?

A) Filing a class action lawsuit arguing that the arbitration clause is unconscionable under state law
B) Initiating individual arbitration proceedings for each affected user
C) Petitioning the Federal Trade Commission to investigate and impose fines on the company
D) Seeking to invalidate the entire user agreement based on the company's fraudulent practices

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: This question requires analysis of multiple legal concepts and their real-world application. The correct answer is C for several reasons:

1. The Federal Arbitration Act (FAA) generally upholds mandatory arbitration clauses, even when they prohibit class actions, as reinforced by AT&T Mobility v. Concepcion.

2. Option A is incorrect because state laws cannot declare arbitration clauses unconscionable solely due to class action waivers, as this would be preempted by federal law.

3. Option B, while technically possible, would be impractical and likely ineffective for addressing a widespread issue.

4. Option D is tempting but challenging to achieve. Courts generally separate the arbitration clause from other parts of the agreement, and fraud in the subject matter of the dispute doesn't necessarily invalidate the arbitration clause itself.

5. Option C is the most viable approach because it doesn't directly challenge the arbitration clause. Instead, it leverages a government agency's power to investigate and penalize illegal practices. The FTC has the authority to address deceptive business practices and privacy violations, potentially leading to fines and mandated changes in company behavior without being bound by the arbitration agreement between the company and its users.

This approach also aligns with the question in the documentation about finding a way to address the issue without being a plaintiff in a class action, as the FTC's action could result in broader remedies for affected consumers.

documentation.title: Laws regarding fictitious public figures or celebrities/likenesses/etc.?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: We can already make simple the laws regarding the common scapegoating or scandalous nature of living, human public figures and/or celebrities.

What exactly do laws state about public figures/celebrities that have no immediate, human likeness associated with them? For example, think the [muppets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Muppets), a famous set of characters which are famous, representative of personalities, but are **not real living human beings**.

If a muppet were to be subjected to scrutiny, is the muppet responsible? Is the ventriloquist responsible? Who answers to a muppet if a muppet may not be the work or being of one person?

Alas, what are laws that subject famous characters/personalities/etc. which are not immediate, living humans? Some people run super famous Twitter/social media accounts that represent some visage, likeness or purported being, that of which may not actually be subjected to a real, specific human. As an example, think of a social media account of someone like Elmo, The Annoying Orange, or etc.

Many people can run the account and as such their image or likeness can vary to the public.

Who is responsible though? Assuming we already established that a non\-human can still be a public figure or celebrity, who is ultimately responsible for the actions of a fictional or semi\-fictional person?

Also, what about a smart agent or robot that does machine learning and threatens to kill a major figure, like an official? The programmer didn't do this \-\- the program "learned" words and made that threat via social media/etc. In short, the program COULD in theory be wholly responsible.

This same analogy can apply to a semi\-fictional figure that may not be wholly dictated by the control or means of a human being, or the likeness of one human being either.

By "semi" I mean someone who can partially represent themselves in the form of another likeness/entity they may have made up, but do not fully represent their real personality to such likeness? For example, I could pretend to be "Joe Shaqqa" and use part of my personality to do so, but do not consider myself to be "Joe Shaqqa" and do not associate my real image with this fictional, famous character. Am I fully responsible for "Joe Shaqqa" if I do not consider myself to be Joe Shaqqa, and do not use my complete likeness to represent them, nor only do so myself?

How does the law work with legal issues directed toward fictional or semi\-fictional figures?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Fictional characters are the creation of a person or persons (either natural or legal persons). The 'acts' of the fictional character are the acts of the person who owns/has control of them. 

For example, one would not sue a muppet for a defamation, one would sue the production company(s) who published it.

Question: A popular social media account representing a fictional character "Zappy the Electric Eel" posts content that leads to widespread panic about an imminent power grid failure. The account is jointly managed by a team of marketing professionals from different companies. In determining legal liability for the harmful content, which of the following is the most accurate assessment?

A) The fictional character "Zappy the Electric Eel" bears primary legal responsibility as a public figure
B) The individual team member who wrote the specific post is solely liable for the content
C) Legal responsibility is shared equally among all individuals who have access to manage the account
D) The companies employing the marketing team members could be held jointly liable for the actions of the fictional character

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: This question requires analysis and application of the legal principles discussed in the documentation. The key point is that fictional characters are creations of persons (natural or legal) and the 'acts' of fictional characters are attributed to those who own or control them. In this case, the fictional character "Zappy" is managed by a team from multiple companies, making it a complex scenario.

Option A is incorrect because fictional characters themselves cannot bear legal responsibility. Option B oversimplifies the situation by placing blame solely on one individual, which doesn't align with the shared management described. Option C suggests equal individual responsibility, which doesn't account for the corporate involvement.

Option D is the most accurate because it recognizes that the companies employing the team members could be held jointly liable. This aligns with the principle that those who control the fictional character (in this case, the companies through their employees) are responsible for its actions. It also accounts for the complexity of multiple entities being involved in managing the character, reflecting a real-world scenario where corporate responsibility for social media management of fictional personas can become a legal issue.

documentation.title: Is it possible for a witness to backtrack and claim that their previous statements were wrong because they misremembered?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: One of the Youtube channels I'm following is running a series of videos about an ongoing lawsuit (within reason, of course). The [latest video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9umbsmrFk08) has an interesting point that got me wondering.

Suppose the lawsuit is about events that took place about a long time ago (in the case above it's in 1999, that's over 23 years now). The lawyers of one side are questioning a witness from the other side. The questions are carefully crafted, but in the end they manage to get a statement of the witness that they are sure of some fact X. They even ask them several times, just to be sure.

Then the questioning lawyer produces a photo that clearly shows fact X to be wrong.

Is the witness now allowed to say something along the lines: "Huh. That's odd. I clearly remember it differently. But it's such a small detail and it was so long ago..."? Or is it now considered a deliberate lie?

As for jurisdiction: the above case is in the USA, but since I'm myself from Latvia, I'm interested in generic answers for various jurisdictions (or maybe it's the same everywhere?)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> Is it possible for a witness to backtrack and claim that their previous statements were wrong because they misremembered? ... Is the witness now allowed to say something along the lines: "Huh. That's odd. I clearly remember it differently. But it's such a small detail and it was so long ago..."?

Yes.

> Or is it now considered a deliberate lie?

A judge's assessment of a witness's credibility and reliability is much more nuanced. See ["How is a judge to evaluate a witness's credibility?"](https://law.stackexchange.com/a/85119/46948)

documentation.title: How long can someone keep my server?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Ex employer has a server with their website and archive on it. I bought that server and have receipts. Employer claims they need time to wipe their info from my server. It's been a month already, and employer is still asking for more time. How should I go about getting the server back? USA, DC.

\#\#\# Top Answer: Unless they have some contractual basis for detaining the server that supersedes common law standards, then: After making a clear demand for return, file (probably in small claims court) for relief under the common law principles of [detinue or replevin](https://law.stackexchange.com/q/24425/10).

documentation.title: What are the responsabilities about cited text after original licensor confesses illegal license?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: A book is published containing cited text from an article licensed under some free license like CC\-BY\-SA. With all requirements of such license fulfilled. 

Later on the "author" of the article confesses that it was not original work and did not in fact have the right to grant licenses for the article.

What are the responsabilities of the book's author and publisher?

Is it a copyright infringement to continue publishing it unmodified claiming that any damage is caused by the author of the article and not the book's author whom acted in good faith? 

Otherwise, is it a copyright infringement to reject acting on such revelation until proof is provided about the illegality of the cited article? If the author choses to keep the cited text, is there any obligation to actively investigate the license status?

Note that there is no doubt that the identities of the article's author and the one claiming it was a false license are the same. There is doubt about the veracity of his words though since he must have lied at least once, when he falsely granted a license or when he falsely confessed.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The author of the book has no right to use the text from the article unless permisison has been granted by to holder of the copyright in that article. Since it was taken from a source now known to be infringing, and the original source is not known, it may not legitimately be used until the true author comes forward and grants permission, unless the use would fall under fair use (in the US) or some simialr fair dealing concept (in those countries where that applies).

Of course, the author of the book will suffer no legal penalty unless and until after the true author does come forward and files suit. But the book author could hardly claim 'innocent infringement". The book author is on notice that text has been used with no valid license or grant of permission. It is the book author's responsibility not to use other people's work unless it is in the public domain or permission has been granted in some way. 

Also, a book publisher would be jointly liable in such a case, and might choose to withdraw the book from publication unless some suitable correction is made.

documentation.title: Why does the principle of unreasonableness not involve any consideration of a decision's merits?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I don't understand Lord Greene's standpoint here. What exactly did he mean by "the merits of the decision"? How can unreasonableness not involve any consideration of the decision's merits?

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/CxH2P.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/CxH2P.jpg)

[Online multiple choice question](https://learninglink.oup.com/access/content/faragher-concentrate6e-resources/faragher-concentrate6e-chapter-11-self-test-questions?previousFilter=tag_chapter-11).

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [Wednesbury unreasonableness](https://www.claytonutz.com/knowledge/2019/september/administrative-law-mythbuster-no-01-wednesbury) has two aspects
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

> Lord Greene MR identified two types of unreasonableness:
> 
> 
> * a decision that took into account irrelevant considerations or did not take into account relevant considerations; and
> * where a discretionary decision was "so unreasonable that no reasonable authority could ever have come to it" – and that required "something overwhelming".

Within these boundaries an administrative decision can be wrong, that is, not the decision that a court or another administrative body might have made in the same circumstances. It is not the role of the court to take the decision\-maker’s discretion away \- so long as the decision reached is one that is within the very broad realms of “reasonable” the court will enforce it.

As such, even if the case has been wrongly decided on the facts (“its merits”) it will stand unless the decision is “something overwhelming” in its unreasonableness. Whether it’s a matter of “fundamental importance” or not seems irrelevant.

Which of the following scenarios is most likely to result in the court overturning the council's decision?

A) The court disagrees with the council's interpretation of "public interest" but finds the decision within reasonable bounds.
B) The council considered irrelevant factors like the center's potential political affiliations in making its decision.

D) The decision is unpopular with local residents, but follows established guidelines for permit approvals.

Options A and C are incorrect because they represent situations where the court might disagree with the decision but would not overturn it. This aligns with the explanation that "even if the case has been wrongly decided on the facts ('its merits') it will stand unless the decision is 'something overwhelming' in its unreasonableness." 

Option D is incorrect because unpopularity alone is not grounds for unreasonableness, especially if established guidelines were followed.

This question requires analysis of the Wednesbury principle, application to a real-world scenario, and understanding of the limits of judicial review in administrative decisions. It tests critical thinking about the balance between administrative discretion and judicial oversight, rather than simple recall of facts.

documentation.title: How would Dr. Richard Kimble go about getting himself declared innocent at the end of The Fugitive?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: So I just finished watching The Fugitive. At the end of the film

> Sam Gerard realizes that Kimble is innocent

and takes him into custody. However, at that moment, in the eyes of the law, Kimble is guilty of murdering his wife.

**How would Dr. Kimble go about getting himself declared innocent?** He's already had a trial, so he can't be tried again for the same offense. He obviously needs to appeal, but on what grounds? The trial was conducted properly (we presume), the evidence that would clear his name simply hadn't been uncovered.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You can be tried again for the same offence; double jeopardy only applies if you are found "not guilty". It is not uncommon for appeals courts to invalidate a guilty verdict *and* require a retrial. Similarly a mistrial can result in a new trial at the prosecution's discretion. In addition, some jurisdictions have abolished double jeopardy for crimes like murder (e.g. New South Wales, Australia). 

New evidence coming to light can be grounds for appeal \- in the case of the Fugitive where there have been no appeals this is one avenue open to Kimble.

Where appeals have been exhausted; this is more problematic. One of the principles of justice is that there should be finality to the verdict. Kimble has gone from presumed innocent to presumed guilty \- enough evidence would need to be gathered to demonstrate a clear and unambiguous miscarriage of justice. This may not be within the purview of the judicial branch of government \- he may need a pardon from the executive. In real life (as opposed to Hollywood) Dr. Kimble is still in serious trouble.

In some jurisdictions there may be some "innocence" laws that can allow review of convictions outside the appeal process.

Notwithstanding, Dr. Kimble is going away for a long time for "escaping lawful custody" anyway.
